STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 17, 2022
Debra Matthews
Childrens Center Wayne County
79 West Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48201
RE: License #: CB820201055
Children's Center Wayne Co
79 W Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48202
Dear Ms. Matthews:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 6/8/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and MISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
AMENDED

Licensee Name: Childrens Center Wayne County
Licensee Address: 79 West Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48201

Name of Facility: Children's Center Wayne Co
Facility Address: 79 W Alexandrine
Detroit, MI 48202
Facility Telephone #: (313) 831-5535

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
In one of five new employee records reviewed, one of the
employee’s references dated 4/1/2022 was received after the
employee’s 2/28/2022 date of hire.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of five new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of a central registry clearance completed by the
agency from the state of Illinois and Washington, where the
employee had resided the last 5 years preceding hire.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of seven open foster home records reviewed did not show
documentation that the foster home was provided an application
at least 60 days before the foster home’s pending 7/25/2022
expiration.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
4

calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of seven open foster home records; and one of four closed
foster home records reviewed did not show compliance as
required by the rule:
 The agency’s recommendation in one was submitted on
5/4/2022, seven days before the license was due to
expire on 5/11/2022.
 The agency’s recommendation in the second was
submitted on 7/2/2021, the date of the foster home’s
licensing expiration date.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Three of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of(c) as required by the rule.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
Two of five special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance as required by the rule.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b), as required by the rule.
5

R400.12413 Medical and dental policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall have been completed within 12 months before placement
or a new physical examination shall be completed within 30
calendar days after placement.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record showed the child’s medical due by
10/30/2021 was completed 17 days late on 11/9/2021.
 A second record did not show documentation of the
child’s medical due by 10/29/2021, per the child’s
9/29/2021 date of placement.
R400.12413 Medical and dental policy
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s dental due by 12/28/2021.
R400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of 26 updated service plans (USP) reviewed were late:
 One foster child’s 12/29/2021-3/28/2022 USP was
completed 30 days late on 4/27/2022.
 An independent living youth’s 8/21/2021-11/18/2021 USP
was completed 13 days late on 12/2/2021.
6

Repeat Violation-Renewal 2021(cite under this rule and
R400.12509(3)(o); Interim 2020.
R400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a),
shall include all of the following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404 (4).
(h) The child management plan to be used by the foster parent.
(c):
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
(h):
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the specific behavior management plan to be
used for the child.
R400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Two of four family adoption evaluation records reviewed showed
an adoption evaluation was not completed within 90 days of the
respective family’s 5/24/2021 and 9/23/2021 application date.
R400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
One of four approved adoptive family records reviewed did not
show documentation of compliance as required by the rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
7

None this inspection.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be completed
each quarter.
Six of eight child adoption records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Two child’s records did not show documentation of a
closing quarterly progress report.
 A third child’s record showed the child’s 9/23/2021-
12/22/2021 quarterly was completed 13 days late on
1/4/2022. Additionally, this child’s 12/23/2021- 3/23/2022
quarterly was completed 14 days late on 4/6/2022.
 A fourth child’s 7/13/2021-10/11/2021 quarterly was
completed two days late on 10/13/20221. Additionally,
this child’s 1/4/2022-4/5/2022 quarterly was completed
one day late on 4/6/2022.
 A fifth child’s 9/29/2021-12/28/2021 quarterly was
completed seven days late on 1/4/2022. This child’s
12/29/2021-3/29/2022 quarterly was completed eight
days late on 4/6/2022.
 A sixth child’s 11/12/2021-2/10/2022 quarterly was
completed over two months late on 4/28/2022. This
child’s next quarterly due for May 2022 was not
documented.
ADM 980 Closing Documentation.
Adoption Closing Summary
A copy of the closing summary must be sent within 14 calendar
days of the adoption finalization date to the foster care worker
and the Department of Health and Services (DHHS) adoption
monitor for purchase of service cases for inclusion in the child’s
permanent record
Two of five finalized adoption records reviewed showed the
child’s closing summary (DHHS 222) was completed more than
14 days after the child’s respective 7/23/2021 and 8/19/2021
finalization date.
8

FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out lined in the following table.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed, and two of six
open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the standard:
 One child’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the child’s 12/1/2021-12/30/2021 ISP. One was
completed after the period on 1/24/2022.
 A second child’s record did not show documentation of
an FTM for the child’s 9/13/2021-12/11/2021 USP.
Additionally, a DHS-1105 was not documented for a
reported 6/2/2021 FTM.
 A third child’s record did not show documentation of a
FTM for the child’s 1/6/2022-4/5/2022 USP.
 One independent living youth’s record did not show
documentation of an FTM for the youth’s 9/29/2021-
10/19/2021 USP.
 A second independent living youth’s record did not show
documentation of an FTM for the youth’s 5/18/2021-
8/13/2022 USP. One was completed sooner than
required on 6/4/2021; and after the period on 9/20/2021.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2020.
FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts.
At minimum, the primary foster care caseworker assigned to the
case must complete case contacts according to the
requirements listed in this item.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed showed various
social work contacts of homes visits in the caregiver, and or
birth parent home which did not show consistent documentation
of a quality visit as defined by the standard.
9

The respective contact was very brief and did not consistently
indicate whether there was an assessment of medical, physical
and or mental health needs related the child, discussion of the
case plan, or indication in the narrative of what type of
engagement occurred with the child or person or if the child had
opportunity to ask questions alone, if applicable.
FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, And Timeframes.
Supervisor Approval:
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Seven of 37 services plans reviewed did not meet compliance:
One child’s:
 5/3/2021--7/31/2022 USP completed on 7/31/2021 was
approved three days late on 8/17/2021.
 1/29/2022-4/27/2022 USP completed on 4/27/2022 was
approved two days late on 5/13/2022.
A second child’s:
 3/17/2021-6/14/2021 USP completed on 6/14/2021 was
approved one day late on 6/29/2021.
 6/15/2021-9/12/2021 USP completed on 9/12/2021 was
approved 18 days late on 10/14/2021.
 9/13/2021-12/11/2021 USP completed on 12/11/2021
was approved 58 days late on 2/21/2022.
 12/12/2021-3/11/2022 USP completed on 3/11/2022 was
approved one day late on 3/26/2022.
A third child’s:
 1/21/2022-4/20/2022 USP completed on 4/20/2022 was
approved 13 days late on 5/17/2022.
Repeat Violation- Cited under 722-9 Renewal 2021; Interim
2020.
FOM 722 8D Treatment plans.
Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
10

The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Three of 37 service plans reviewed did not show compliance:
 One child’s 9/13/2021-12/11/2021 treatment plan was not
signed by the caregiver until 2/23/2022.
 A second child’s 1/6/2022-4/5/2022 treatment plan was
signed by the caregiver.
 A third record for an independent living youth’s
5/23/2021-8/20/2021 treatment plan was not signed by
the youth until 11/12/2021.
 A fourth record for an independent living youth’s
10/12/2021-1/9/2022 treatment plan was not signed by
the youth until 4/8/2022.
Repeat Violation- cited under 722-8C Renewal 2021; Interim
2020.
FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
The caseworker must complete the DHS-69, Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, and upload to
MiSACWIS within the timeframe required for the specified
change.
 Three days prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement
change.
Two of eight open foster child records; and two of six open
independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One child’s record did not show documentation of a DHS-
69 for the child’s 1/21/2022 return home.
 A second child’s record showed the DHS-69 for the
child’s 10/26/2021 change of placement was completed
three days late on 11/3/2021.
 A third record for an independent living youth showed the
DHS-69 for the youth’s 5/31/2021 placement change was
completed late on 8/19/2021
 A fourth record for an independent living youth showed
the DHS-69 for the youth’s 1/4/2022 placement change
was completed late on 3/30/2022.
FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
The caseworker must provide the following documents to the
child's legal parent/guardian, or to the youth if the youth is age
11

18 or older or has been legally emancipated, at the time of
closure:
 A certified copy of the child's birth certificate (retain a
copy in the case record).
 The child's social security card. Note: In cases where the
social security number has been verified and
documented per policy, the caseworker must make
efforts to obtain a social security card. •
Two of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule.
FOM 801 Dental examination schedule.
A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every six
months unless greater frequency is indicated.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
document of the child’s re-examination due by 2/13/2021, and
8/13/2021.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward; Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement;
and at reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each
placement and quarterly.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 Two did not show consistent documentation that the
medical passport was completed quarterly.
 A third did not show documentation the medical passport
was provided to the caregiver quarterly.
FOM 802 Mental Health and Behavioral and Developmental Need of
Children under supervision of MDHHS.
All children entering foster care are required to have a mental
health screening within 30 days of removal. The screening
instrument must be completed by a person who knows the child
best, before the child's Early Periodic, Screening, Diagnostic,
and Treatment (EPSTD)/well child exam.
12

One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s screening was completed on 3/17/2022, more than 30
days after the child’s 9/23/2021 date of placement
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
4.22 MISACWIS
 Foster parent social work contacts shall be consistently documented for all
records.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12511(2)(d)
 Including a statement in the youth closing DHS-69 Action summary that the youth
has received all their funds and property may aid in showing compliance to the
rule.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2021 Renewal Inspection where it
received the following citations:
 R400.12418(2)(a) &(b)- Development of service plans.
 R400.12509(3)(o)-Independent living record.
 FOM-722-9- Supervisory approval- for updated service plans.
 FOM 722-08C- Parent agency treatment plan agreement.
 FOM 722-06H – Timely entry of case worker contacts.
.
The agency has effectively completed tools identified in its corrective action plan but
were not totally successful with completion of the corrective action plan related to all
rule compliance. They received a couple of repeat violations as indicated in this
report.
DCWL ANAYLST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
One safety alert was received:
Concern:
The unlicensed relative is not responding to calls for a visit in the home for the annual
13

audit. Please verify the well-being of the child in the home.
Resolution:
The agency made contact with the relative caregiver on 3/30/2022 and advised the
relative caregiver that the DCWL Analyst was attempting to contact her. The relative
caregiver was provided the DCWL Analyst’s name and number; and was advised to
contact the DCWL Analyst. The relative caregiver recalled the DCWL Analyst had called
her, but she did not realize who that person was. The agency’s assigned worker also
conducted a relative home visit on 3/30/2022 at 6pm. The child’s well-being was
verified; and no safety concerns were observed.
VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date: June 16, 2022
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 17, 2022

Area Manager
14
